nodes.text: The impact of retirement savings policies on wealth accumulation depends on whether they operate through active choices or passive (automatic) choices
Automatic contributions (employer pensions, mandates) substantially increase total saving and wealth accumulation for affected individuals
Price subsidies for retirement accounts primarily induce asset shifting across accounts and generate large crowd-out, producing little net new saving

Individuals separate into active savers (~15%) who reoptimize with price changes and passive savers (~85%) who are unresponsive to subsidies but respond to automatic contributions; active savers tend to be wealthier and more financially sophisticated

Method: Administrative panel for the population of Denmark, 1995-2009, 41 million person-year observations on flows into retirement accounts and taxable account wealth, linked to employer and tax records

Evidence from firm-switch event studies: when workers move to a firm that increases employer retirement contributions by DKr 1, total saving increases by about 0.78 DKr (approx 78 cents) holding total compensation fixed; pass-through of employer contributions to total pensions ≈ 0.94

Evidence from Mandatory Savings Plan (MSP) RD: introducing a 1% mandated contribution raised total saving near the eligibility cutoff with estimated pass-through to total saving close to or above 0.8, i.e. most of the mandated contribution increased total saving

Evidence from 1999 capital-pension subsidy reduction (DiD, top tax bracket): individual capital pension contributions fell sharply for treated incomes, with large changes concentrated among a minority of prior contributors

Within-retirement-account crowd-out: when capital pension subsidy was reduced, about 57% of the withdrawn capital-pension contributions were shifted into annuity pensions, so total pension contributions fell by about 0.43 DKr per DKr reduction in capital pensions

Crowd-out of taxable saving: IV/MPS and threshold estimates imply roughly 0.98–0.99 DKr of each DKr withdrawn from retirement accounts was replaced by taxable saving; overall each DKr of government subsidy generated near zero net new saving (point estimate ~0.01 DKr), upper 95% CI ~0.28 DKr

Heterogeneity evidence: individuals who newly start or frequently change pensions, are older, wealthier, or have economics/finance training are more responsive to price subsidies and more likely to offset automatic contributions; the majority (≈85%) behave passively

Conclusion: Automatic contributions are more effective than subsidies at increasing total savings because (1) subsidies induce few to respond, (2) responding individuals largely shift assets rather than add net saving, and (3) subsidies mostly aﬀect active, already-planning savers while automatic contributions raise saving among passive, less-prepared individuals
